head.title: Hot Town, Electric Summer in the City

hedline.hl1: Hot Town, Electric Summer in the City

abstract.p: Edward A Smeloff letter says only realistic short-term solution to assure a reliable power supply for New york City is a crash program to retrofit existing buildings so that they will be more energy efficient; drawing

block.p: Re ''Powering a Hot City'' (editorial, July 9): The only realistic short-term solution to assure a reliable power supply for New York City for the next several summers is a crash program to retrofit existing buildings so that they will be more energy efficient.

Simple measures like replacing inefficient lighting systems and tuning up air-conditioning and ventilation equipment can result in substantial peak-demand reductions that will lower electricity prices in the wholesale market.

Re ''Powering a Hot City'' (editorial, July 9): The only realistic short-term solution to assure a reliable power supply for New York City for the next several summers is a crash program to retrofit existing buildings so that they will be more energy efficient.

Simple measures like replacing inefficient lighting systems and tuning up air-conditioning and ventilation equipment can result in substantial peak-demand reductions that will lower electricity prices in the wholesale market.

New Jersey had an effective program in the mid-1990's to pay energy service contractors for measured and verifiable energy reductions in summer peak load. Such a program could be started quickly in New York City if the New York Public Service Commission ordered Consolidated Edison to do so.
EDWARD A. SMELOFF White Plains, July 10, 2000
The writer is the executive director of the Pace Law School Energy Project.
